study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Cytoflavin (containing Riboflavin) in improving rehabilitation outcomes for patients with post-intensive care syndrome (PICS) after ischemic stroke.
results_summary: Cytoflavin did not reduce the time for normalization of the gravitational gradient but improved activity recovery (Barthel index) in ischemic stroke patients with PICS. A new prospective study will further assess its role in rehabilitation.
population_specificity: Patients with ischemic stroke and post-intensive care syndrome (PICS), hospitalized for stages 2-3 of rehabilitation (14-60 days post-stroke).
effective_dosage: Not specified (Cytoflavin administered intravenously for 10 days).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether β-ionone treatment could slow the loss of riboflavin and other bioactive substances in postharvest broccoli by upregulating biosynthetic genes.
results_summary: β-ionone treatment upregulated riboflavin biosynthetic genes in broccoli, delaying nutrient loss and enhancing antioxidant capacity during storage.
population_specificity: Postharvest broccoli florets

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether biliary-intestinal anastomosis during pancreaticoduodenectomy alters intestinal microbiota and metabolites, including riboflavin metabolism, and its potential link to long-term complications.
results_summary: The study identified riboflavin metabolism as one of nine key metabolic pathways altered post-surgery, but did not specifically evaluate riboflavin's direct effects or outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing pancreaticoduodenectomy (17 in the surgical group, 20 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the vision-related quality of life (vr-QoL) in keratoconus (KC) patients after corneal crosslinking (CXL) with Riboflavin (Vitamin B2).
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant changes in corneal morphology, best corrected visual acuity, or vr-QoL after CXL treatment. Rasch analyses confirmed the KORQ's high measurement precision in this population.
population_specificity: 41 patients with progressive keratoconus (KC).
study_duration: Follow-up at three and six months post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers investigated how micro/nanoplastics disrupt denitrification in wastewater treatment systems, focusing on the role of riboflavin as a redox-active metabolite in the electron transfer process.
results_summary: The study found that micro/nanoplastics exposure reduced riboflavin availability, impairing the denitrification electron transfer process and leading to decreased nitrogen removal efficiency.
population_specificity: Aerobic granular sludge systems (microbial communities in wastewater treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify metabolic markers, including riboflavin metabolism, associated with successful treatment of SLE using mesenchymal stem cell transplantation (MSCT).
results_summary: Pathway analysis indicated riboflavin metabolism was involved in the metabolic changes post-MSCT, but the study primarily focused on thiamine monophosphate (TMP) as a predictive biomarker for treatment success. Clinical improvements were observed, but riboflavin's direct role was not detailed.
population_specificity: 20 patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the interaction of methylene blue (MB) with NADH, FADH2 coenzymes and lactate, and evaluate its long-term effect on tumor metabolism in vivo.
results_summary: MB primarily interacted with NADH, reducing lactate levels and shifting tumor metabolism from glycolysis to oxidative phosphorylation. Oral MB administration showed a decrease in tumor growth rate and metabolic changes, but intravenous MB did not significantly affect tumor growth.
population_specificity: Mice model of Ehrlich carcinoma.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of riboflavin metabolism in the C2 MALAT1+ Tumors subpopulation of HNSCC and its association with reduced metabolic pathway activity.
results_summary: The study found reduced expression of riboflavin metabolism pathways in the C2 MALAT1+ Tumors subpopulation, suggesting a potential link between riboflavin metabolism and tumor progression in HNSCC. No direct effects or clinical outcomes related to riboflavin supplementation were reported.
population_specificity: Patients with head and neck squamous cell carcinoma (HNSCC), specifically the C2 MALAT1+ Tumors subpopulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop and evaluate riboflavin-based hydrogel and co-crystal formulations for non-invasive corneal cross-linking treatment in keratoconus.
results_summary: The study identified promising riboflavin co-crystals (1R1N and 1R1M) and thermosensitive gels, with riboflavin formulations showing superior corneal retention and prolonged contact time compared to riboflavin-5-phosphate sodium. The THJ-TP formulation emerged as the most effective candidate.
population_specificity: Rat corneas (in vivo), with additional in vitro and ex vivo evaluations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the wound healing response and biomechanical changes in the cornea following Riboflavin-ultraviolet-crosslinking (RIB-UV-CXL) treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the classical "epithelium-off" RIB-UV-CXL method is more effective in halting ectasia progression than "epithelium-on" methods. Corneal transparency is restored over months as stromal cells revert to keratocytes, and biomechanical studies confirm CXL strengthens corneal tissue.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing corneal treatment for ectasia (specific population details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of the riboflavin-phosphocholine-light (RPL) system on cancer cell viability, transdifferentiation, and potential therapeutic applications.
results_summary: The RPL system induced lysozyme photopolymerization, affected cancer cell viability, and caused morphological changes. It also led to transdifferentiation of triple-negative breast cancer cells into osteoblast-like cells and cell death in specific hydrogel conditions.
population_specificity: Cancer cells (2D and 3D cultures), nontumoral cells, mesenchymal stem cells, and triple-negative breast cancer cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the holistic mechanism of Kai-Xin-San (KXS), including its impact on riboflavin metabolism, in ameliorating cognitive deficits and pathological changes in Alzheimer's disease (AD) rats.
results_summary: The study identified riboflavin metabolism as one of the key pathways affected by KXS, suggesting its role in reducing oxidative stress, neurotoxicity, and inflammation in AD rats. Multi-omics analysis linked these effects to improved cognitive function and hippocampal morphology.
population_specificity: AD-induced rat model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness and safety of combining customized PRK (cPRK) with corneal cross-linking (CXL) versus CXL alone in improving visual outcomes for patients with progressive keratoconus.
results_summary: The combination of CXL+cPRK significantly improved postoperative visual acuity (UDVA and CDVA) and reduced refractive cylinder error compared to CXL alone, while maintaining corneal stability. No significant differences were observed in endothelial cell count or ectasia progression rates between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive keratoconus (731 eyes from 706 patients).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the long-term efficacy, safety, and prognostic factors of pulsed-light accelerated corneal collagen cross-linking (A-CXL) with continuous riboflavin application for halting keratoconus progression.
results_summary: A-CXL with 10-minute riboflavin application showed a higher success rate (89%) in halting keratoconus progression compared to 5-minute application (71%). The 10-minute group also demonstrated significant improvements in visual acuity, keratometry, and corneal irregularity, with no significant adverse effects on corneal thickness or endothelial cell density.
population_specificity: 37 eyes of 33 patients with progressive keratoconus.
effective_dosage: Continuous riboflavin application for either 5 or 10 minutes.
study_duration: Follow-up between 2016 and 2020 (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of riboflavin-mediated photodynamic therapy (PDT) in periodontology, focusing on its antimicrobial effects and clinical outcomes compared to conventional or other PDT-based treatments.
results_summary: Riboflavin-mediated PDT consistently reduced microbial biofilms and pathogen viability in periodontal, peri-implantitis, and endodontic models, with advantages like minimal staining and low cytotoxicity, though some studies reported slightly lower efficacy compared to other PDT agents. Most studies were in vitro or small-scale clinical trials, limiting conclusions on long-term effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with periodontitis, peri-implantitis, and endodontic infections (primarily in vitro and small-scale clinical trials).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether probiotic supplementation, which included Riboflavin (Vitamin B2), could improve nutrient intake and quality of life in Crohn's disease patients.
results_summary: The study found that probiotic supplementation led to increased riboflavin intake in the intervention group compared to controls (p = 0.04), but no direct effects on disease symptoms were observed.
population_specificity: Lebanese patients with Crohn's disease (n = 21).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the progress on riboflavin-UVA collagen cross-linking depth and its relationship with the cross-linking effect to enhance its clinical application in treating corneal and scleral diseases.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin-UVA collagen cross-linking demonstrated good clinical efficacy in treating various corneal diseases and showed initial confirmation of efficacy and safety in scleral collagen cross-linking. It emphasized the importance of controllability and predictability for personalized precision treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with corneal diseases (e.g., dilatation keratopathy, bullae keratopathy, infectious keratopathy) and those undergoing corneal refractive surgeries.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate riboflavin-ultraviolet light treatment as a promising alternative to reduce transfusion transmission of Trypanosoma cruzi in blood banks.
results_summary: The study highlights riboflavin-ultraviolet light treatment as an innovative approach to enhance blood safety, potentially reducing the risk of Chagas disease transmission through transfusions. It positions riboflavin-based methods alongside arylimidamide compounds as advancements in blood bank safety protocols.
population_specificity: Blood donors and recipients, particularly in endemic and non-endemic regions for Chagas disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to demonstrate the use of multiphoton microscopy with fluorescence lifetime imaging (MPM-FLIM) to monitor metabolic changes during epidermal differentiation of keratinocytes.
results_summary: The study found that MPM-FLIM could effectively monitor keratinocyte differentiation by detecting shifts from glycolysis to mitochondrial respiration, correlating with increased oxidative phosphorylation after high calcium treatment. Differentiation markers keratin-1 and keratin-10 were upregulated, and clusters based on MPM-FLIM data correlated well with the duration of high Ca2+ treatment.
population_specificity: In vitro 2D keratinocyte tissue culture model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of riboflavin (RF) combined with ultraviolet A (UV-A) cross-linking (CXL) in enhancing corneal resistance to enzymatic digestion, with or without oxygen.
results_summary: The study found that CXL via RB/green and RB/green-RF/UV-A significantly increased corneal resistance to collagenase digestion, regardless of oxygen presence, with higher fluences (15 + 15 J/cm²) showing the greatest effect. No significant differences were observed between control and intervention groups.
population_specificity: Ex vivo porcine corneal buttons (n = 144)
effective_dosage: Fluences of 10 + 10 J/cm² and 15 + 15 J/cm² for RB/green + RF/UV-A

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of riboflavin-derived microbial metabolites in activating MAIT cells and their therapeutic potential in immunity and disease.
results_summary: The study highlighted that MAIT cells recognize riboflavin biosynthesis pathway metabolites, triggering immune responses, and discussed their potential in immunotherapy for infections, cancers, and autoimmune diseases.
population_specificity: Not specified (review of MAIT cell biology and therapeutic applications).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of riboflavin biosynthesis in L. paraplantarum and its potential impact on S. aureus virulence gene expression through quorum sensing suppression.
results_summary: The study found that L. paraplantarum's lamBDCA locus controls riboflavin biosynthesis genes, enabling growth in the presence of roseoflavin, a toxic riboflavin analogue. This suggests riboflavin biosynthesis plays a role in the probiotic properties of L. paraplantarum.
population_specificity: Bacterial cultures (L. paraplantarum CIRM-BIA 1870 and S. aureus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of riboflavin biosynthesis upregulation in the antibacterial mechanism of the AZC/Van@MN patch for treating abscess wounds.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin biosynthesis was upregulated as part of the antibacterial mechanism of the AZC/Van@MN patch, contributing to its effectiveness in reducing bacterial load and enhancing wound healing.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely animal or in vitro model based on the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether violet light (VL) irradiation alone, without topical riboflavin, could halt keratoconus progression.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in keratoconus progression between patients receiving VL irradiation alone and the control group, suggesting riboflavin administration was necessary for effective treatment.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive keratoconus
effective_dosage: Not specified (VL irradiation at 375 nm, 310 μW/cm² for 4.5 h daily)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of riboflavin (Vitamin B2) as part of a dietary intervention in treating late-onset multiple acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency (MADD).
results_summary: Riboflavin supplementation (400 mg TID) combined with other dietary supplements led to almost complete recovery of the patient's habitual level within one month, with posttreatment muscle biopsy showing improved myofiber ultrastructure.
population_specificity: A 52-year-old male patient with rapid-onset, late-stage MADD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the structural and functional characteristics of H. pylori DHODH (HpDHODH) and its interaction with flavin mononucleotide (FMN), a derivative of riboflavin, to facilitate drug development targeting this enzyme.
results_summary: The study detailed the crystal structure of HpDHODH, identified key interactions with FMN, and discovered a hydrophobic channel linking the enzyme's active site to the membrane, which may aid in developing new inhibitors. The findings provide a structural basis for competitive inhibition of ubiquinone by pyrazole-based compounds.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on H. pylori enzyme)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of Cytoflavin (containing Riboflavin) in strengthening pathogenic therapy for autoimmune central nervous system diseases triggered by viral infections.
results_summary: The abstract suggests Cytoflavin has a complex effect on improving metabolic processes in the brain, but specific outcomes related to Riboflavin's efficacy are not detailed.
population_specificity: Patients with autoimmune central nervous system diseases triggered by viral infections (influenza, measles, SARS-CoV-2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the active anti-inflammatory substances in GCFZT, including riboflavin, and explore their mechanisms of action.
results_summary: The study identified riboflavin as one of the main active substances in GCFZT, contributing to its anti-inflammatory effects by regulating targets like ALOX5, NFKB1, and TLR4, and influencing pathways such as NF-κB and Toll-like receptor signaling.
population_specificity: In vitro study using LPS-induced RAW264.7 inflammatory cell model.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in visual acuity and corneal topography parameters before and six months after Accelerated Collagen Crosslinking (A-CXL) treatment using Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) for keratoconus.
results_summary: The study found improved best-corrected visual acuity (BCVA), reduced cylinder diopters and Kmax values, and increased central and thinnest corneal thickness (CCT, TCT) after A-CXL. Minor, non-significant changes were observed in specific topography markers at six months.
population_specificity: 30 eyes from 20 patients with keratoconus who underwent A-CXL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of transepithelial iontophoresis-assisted corneal cross-linking (I-CXL) using Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) in halting the progression of keratoconus, particularly in younger patients and those with specific phenotypes.
results_summary: The study found that I-CXL with Riboflavin did not effectively stop keratoconus progression over two years, especially in patients under 19 years old. Progression was more pronounced in patients with a family history of corneal ectasia and specific keratoconus phenotypes (3 and 4).
population_specificity: 40 eyes (20 aged <19 years and 20 aged ≥19 years) with progressive keratoconus.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify angiogenesis-related genes, including those in the riboflavin metabolic pathway, as potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets for hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).
results_summary: The study found that high-risk HCC patients showed elevated activity in the riboflavin metabolic pathway, suggesting a potential role in tumor progression, but did not directly assess riboflavin's therapeutic effects.
population_specificity: Patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of riboflavin metabolism in the C2 IGF2+ tumor cell subtype of high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC) and its association with tumor progression and prognosis.
results_summary: The study identified that the C2 IGF2+ tumor cell subtype, associated with poor prognosis, was linked to riboflavin metabolism among other metabolic pathways, suggesting a potential role in tumor malignancy and progression. However, the abstract does not provide specific outcomes or clinical effects of riboflavin itself.
population_specificity: Patients with high-grade serous ovarian cancer (HGSOC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate changes in riboflavin (Vitamin B2) levels in adolescents undergoing bonded rapid maxillary expansion (RME) treatment.
results_summary: Riboflavin levels were significantly lower at the first week of treatment (T2) compared to baseline (T1), but rebounded by the fourth (T3) and 12th week (T4). The study suggests RME treatment temporarily affects riboflavin intake or absorption.
population_specificity: 30 adolescents (12-16 years, 21 girls and 9 boys) with maxillary posterior crossbite.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to enhance transepithelial riboflavin penetration in bovine corneas using modified nanoparticles under an external magnetic field to improve corneal cross-linking efficacy.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin penetration increased with higher electric current density (iontophoresis) and stronger magnetic fields (nanoparticle-assisted delivery), demonstrating improved corneal permeability compared to control groups.
population_specificity: Ex vivo bovine corneas

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the biological pathway changes in rabbit corneas induced by riboflavin-dextran (RF-D) with UVA illumination versus WST-D with NIR illumination for corneal stiffening.
results_summary: RF-D/UVA treatment shifted corneal metabolism from oxidative phosphorylation to glycolysis and hypoxia, while WST-D/NIR maintained normal respiration and involved extracellular matrix remodeling. Both treatments showed distinct protein expression changes compared to untreated corneas.
population_specificity: Rabbit corneas (mechanically de-epithelialized).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of OMK2 eye drops (containing citicoline, vitamin B12, and hyaluronic acid) on corneal nerve healing and central corneal thickness recovery after corneal cross-linking (CXL) in keratoconus patients.
results_summary: The study found that OMK2 eye drops helped maintain corneal nerve fiber area (CNFA) stability and supported faster recovery of central corneal thickness (CCT) compared to the control group, though other nerve parameters declined in both groups. No significant differences were observed in corneal sensitivity or tear film stability between groups.
population_specificity: 22 patients (44 eyes) with keratoconus who underwent CXL.
effective_dosage: Not specified (OMK2 eye drops used as per standard post-CXL treatment).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether riboflavin-enriched compounds could improve neurological symptoms in an adult patient with L-2-hydroxyglutaric aciduria.
results_summary: The patient showed improvement in ataxia symptoms, with the SARA score decreasing from 21 to 15 after six months of riboflavin and levocarnitine treatment. The case suggests that riboflavin intervention may benefit untreated adult patients with this condition.
population_specificity: A 49-year-old female with L-2-hydroxyglutaric aciduria presenting with neurological symptoms.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore metabolic pathway alterations, including riboflavin metabolism, in acne vulgaris lesions to understand its role in the condition's pathogenesis.
results_summary: The study identified specific alterations in riboflavin metabolism pathways in acne vulgaris lesions, suggesting a potential role in the condition's cellular and molecular mechanisms. However, no direct efficacy of riboflavin supplementation was evaluated.
population_specificity: Six acne vulgaris patients (data sourced from GEO database GSE175817).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate different riboflavin-ultraviolet-A (RF-UVA) treatments for their ability to preserve dentin bonding from enzymatic digestion.
results_summary: The study found that 0.1% RF with 2-minute UVA treatment effectively enhanced dentin bond strength and resistance to enzymatic digestion, showing the highest microtensile bond strength and minimal nanoleakage. Other RF-UVA treatments also demonstrated collagen crosslinking effects but were less effective.
population_specificity: Human teeth with exposed dentin (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 0.1% and 1% riboflavin with UVA exposure durations of 1, 2, or 5 minutes.
study_duration: Immediate testing after 24-hour storage, with some specimens stored in enzyme solution for 7 days.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of riboflavin-mediated antimicrobial photodynamic therapy (aPDT) as an alternative treatment for Candida infections, particularly focusing on its antifungal activity and potential to address resistance.
results_summary: Riboflavin-mediated aPDT demonstrated significant antifungal activity against Candida biofilms and planktonic cells, including fluconazole-resistant strains, with minimal cytotoxicity to host tissues. However, complete biofilm eradication remained challenging, and protocol variations indicated a need for standardization.
population_specificity: Candida albicans infections, including fluconazole-resistant strains.

study_goal: The researchers investigated the metabolic profile of etodolac, including pathways involving riboflavin, to identify associations with drug response and side effects.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin-related metabolites were correlated with hematological and liver function parameters, suggesting a potential role in etodolac's metabolic effects, but no direct outcomes on riboflavin itself were reported.
population_specificity: Thirty-seven healthy volunteers
study_duration: Single dose of etodolac (duration not specified for riboflavin)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of riboflavin combined with UV radiation in enhancing collagen cross-linking and tissue integration following xenographic lenticule implantation for treating corneal ectasias.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin application followed by UV radiation improved collagen fibril cross-linking, increased stromal thickness, and showed no signs of tissue rejection in rabbits. The combination demonstrated promising results for corneal ectasia treatment.
population_specificity: Rabbits with corneal stromal implantation of decellularized porcine lenticules.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether riboflavin activated by blue light (BL) strengthens collagen matrix, increases resistance to enzymatic degradation, and improves adhesion as effectively as ultraviolet A (UVA) activation in dentin bonding.
results_summary: Both RF/UVA and RF/BL treatments enhanced collagen crosslinking, improved mechanical properties of demineralized dentin, and inhibited matrix metalloproteinase-2. RF0.1 groups (0.1% RF with BL or UVA) maintained high bond strength post-degradation, with RF0.1BL1 producing a thicker hybrid layer.
population_specificity: Demineralized dentin samples (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 0.1% and 1% riboflavin, with 1 or 2 minutes of blue light (450 nm) or 2 minutes of UVA (375 nm) irradiation.
study_duration: Immediate post-treatment and 7-day enzymatic degradation testing.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the potential impact of expanding large-scale food fortification programs, including riboflavin, on reducing micronutrient inadequacies among women of reproductive age and children in Senegal.
results_summary: Expanding wheat flour fortification to include riboflavin was predicted to have a modest impact on reducing riboflavin inadequacies, though larger effects were seen for other micronutrients like vitamin B12 and zinc. The study suggested that additional interventions might be needed to fully address micronutrient gaps.
population_specificity: Women of reproductive age (15-49 years) and children (6-59 months) in Senegal.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of riboflavin (RF) in cross-linking silk fibroin (SF) to enhance biodegradability and nontoxicity in an injectable skin substitute for burn wound therapy.
results_summary: Riboflavin was used to chimically cross-link silk fibroin under visible light, contributing to the desirable biodegradability and nontoxicity of the skin substitute. The resulting double cross-linked structure demonstrated optimal adhesion, biocompatibility, and faster wound healing in animal models.
population_specificity: Rat models (liver injury and wound healing).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether regional scleral cross-linking (SXL) with riboflavin and UVA affects ocular rigidity and intraocular pressure (IOP) in porcine eyes.
results_summary: The study found that SXL-treated scleras showed increased stiffness but did not induce substantial changes in ocular rigidity or significant IOP elevations compared to controls. The ocular rigidity coefficient in the SXL group remained stable despite IOP increases.
population_specificity: Fresh porcine eye globes (n=40, divided into experimental and control groups).
effective_dosage: Not specified (riboflavin and UVA application described as regional).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of riboflavin metabolism in oxidative stress and inflammatory responses during different energy levels of femtosecond laser-assisted cataract surgery (FLACS).
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin metabolism was significantly overexpressed in high-energy FLACS compared to low-energy FLACS, suggesting its involvement in oxidative stress and mitochondrial fatty acid oxidation pathways.
population_specificity: 72 patients undergoing cataract surgery, randomized into low-energy FLACS, high-energy FLACS, and conventional phacoemulsification groups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate and characterize a riboflavin-overproducing strain of Weissella confusa (FS54 B2) and evaluate its potential for developing functional beverages.
results_summary: The mutant strain FS54 B2 overproduced riboflavin (4.9 mg/L in synthetic medium, 2.4 mg/L in oat-based beverage) and retained dextran production. Fermentation in oat-based beverages also yielded prebiotics and antioxidants, with confirmed pH-lowering ability and cell viability after one month.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and food matrix testing).
effective_dosage: Not specified (measured as 2.4 mg/L in fermented oat beverage).
study_duration: Not specified (fermentation and one-month storage tested).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a combined same-session treatment using riboflavin/UV-A and rose bengal/green light PACK-CXL for treating Acanthamoeba keratitis (AK) resistant to conventional therapy.
results_summary: The study found that the combined same-session PACK-CXL treatment effectively resolved symptoms and eradicated Acanthamoeba cysts in a patient with AK unresponsive to conventional therapy, suggesting potential as an alternative treatment.
population_specificity: A 44-year-old patient with active AK in the left cornea unresponsive to 10 months of conventional treatment.
effective_dosage: Riboflavin/UV-A (365 nm) irradiation (10 J/cm²) and rose bengal/green light (522 nm) irradiation (5.4 J/cm²) in a single setting, repeated twice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cytoflavin (containing Riboflavin) in reducing cognitive impairment, fatigue, and depressive disorders in elderly and senile patients recovering from COVID-19-associated pneumonia during outpatient rehabilitation.
results_summary: The study found that Cytoflavin significantly improved cognitive function, reduced fatigue and depressive symptoms, enhanced emotional well-being, and increased exercise tolerance in the treated group compared to controls.
population_specificity: Elderly and senile patients (average age 66.5±5.1 years) recovering from COVID-19-associated pneumonia in an outpatient setting.
effective_dosage: Standard regimen (specific dosage not mentioned in abstract).
study_duration: Duration not explicitly stated in abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of Cytoflavin (containing Riboflavin) and nursing interventions in improving outcomes for patients with spinal cord injuries.
results_summary: Patients receiving Cytoflavin showed significantly greater improvement in muscle strength and neurological function compared to the control group, with a 4.6 times higher likelihood of transitioning to milder neurological severity.
population_specificity: 40 patients with spinal cord injuries due to gunshot wounds.
effective_dosage: Intravenous Cytoflavin infusions followed by tablet form (specific dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Cytoflavin (containing Riboflavin) on autonomic dysfunction and asthenia in patients with post-COVID syndrome.
results_summary: Cytoflavin therapy improved heart rate variability (HRV) parameters and reduced asthenia severity, normalizing parasympathetic regulation in post-COVID patients. The treatment group showed significant improvement compared to the standard therapy group.
population_specificity: 70 patients with post-COVID syndrome, divided into two groups (one receiving Cytoflavin + standard therapy, the other only standard therapy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare metabolic changes, including riboflavin metabolism, in dental plaque between patients using fixed appliances and clear aligners during orthodontic treatment.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin metabolism was downregulated in the clear aligner group after more than 6 months of treatment, suggesting a metabolic shift, but did not evaluate direct health outcomes related to riboflavin.
population_specificity: 20 participants undergoing orthodontic treatment (10 with fixed appliances, 10 with clear aligners).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) as a natural photosensitizer in Photodynamic Therapy (PDT) and its therapeutic applications.
results_summary: Riboflavin demonstrated significant potential in preclinical in vitro studies across various cell lines, showing effectiveness in inducing apoptosis, autophagy, and ROS generation for therapeutic efficacy. The review highlighted its advantages, including specific targeting, bioavailability, and limited side effects.
population_specificity: Preclinical studies (in vitro and in vivo models, including skin tumors, carcinomas, and sarcomas).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the molecular changes induced by a chemical cross-linker (CXL) using carbodiimide chemistry and an octanedioic acid spacer as an alternative to conventional UV-A Riboflavin crosslinking for treating keratoconus.
results_summary: The CXL stiffened keratoconus corneas comparably to normal corneas, with minimal cytotoxicity. It reorganized collagen fiber assembly, increased fibril density and diameter, and reduced the activity and secretion of MMPs in corneal tissues and cells.
population_specificity: Keratoconus corneal tissues and in vitro cellular systems (KC corneal fibroblasts and TNF-α-induced human corneal epithelial cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of riboflavin and probenecid in a zebrafish model of Riboflavin Transporter Deficiency (RTD).
results_summary: Riboflavin treatment improved locomotor activity and hearing ability in zebrafish with RTD-like symptoms, while co-treatment with probenecid provided a small additional benefit to hearing but not locomotion. The study confirmed the model's ability to replicate RTD phenotypes and riboflavin responsiveness.
population_specificity: Zebrafish larvae with morpholino-mediated knockdown of slc52a3 (a human SLC52A3 ortholog).
interactions: Probenecid (OAT-3 inhibitor) was tested in combination with riboflavin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore advancements in corneal cross-linking (CXL) protocols using riboflavin (Vitamin B2) to improve treatment efficacy, safety, and applicability for corneal ectasia and other corneal conditions.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin-based CXL protocols effectively stiffen the cornea, counteract ectasia-induced weakening, and have expanded applications, including treating infectious keratitis (PACK-CXL). Accelerated protocols maintain efficacy and safety while improving clinical workflow.
population_specificity: Patients with progressive keratoconus, corneal ectasias, corneal neovascularization, sterile melting, inflammatory dry eye, and infectious keratitis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (original "Dresden" protocol involves riboflavin saturation of the stroma followed by UV-A irradiation).
study_duration: Original protocol involves 30 minutes of UV-A irradiation; accelerated protocols vary.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether electroacupuncture (EA) modulates riboflavin levels in depressed rats and its potential role in alleviating depression-like behaviors.
results_summary: The study found that EA intervention modulated riboflavin levels in depressed rats, suggesting its involvement in the therapeutic mechanism of EA for depression. Riboflavin was among the metabolites significantly associated with depression-like behaviors.
population_specificity: Wistar Kyoto (WKY) rats, a model for depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to describe cases of sterile keratitis in pediatric patients following hypotonic collagen cross-linking (CXL) with Riboflavin.
results_summary: Two pediatric cases developed inflammatory keratitis with central corneal haze after CXL, which resolved with treatment, restoring near-preoperative visual acuity. The study highlights a potential adverse effect but demonstrates successful management.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (two children) undergoing hypotonic CXL.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of topical riboflavin (0.1%) combined with UV-A irradiation in corneal collagen cross-linking for progressive keratoconus.
results_summary: The procedure initially led to a sterile infiltrate, which worsened after corticosteroid discontinuation but resolved completely with resumed treatment after 4 months. Riboflavin-assisted cross-linking showed efficacy in the intended application, though with a notable adverse event.
population_specificity: A woman in her early 20s with progressive keratoconus.
effective_dosage: Topical riboflavin 0.1% applied every 3 min for 30 min.
study_duration: 30 min of riboflavin application followed by 16 min of UV-A irradiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the prevalence of inadequate micronutrient intake, including riboflavin, among non-pregnant and non-lactating women of reproductive age in Tanzania.
results_summary: The study found a moderate prevalence of inadequate riboflavin intake (54.8%) among the population, with a nutrient gap in the first quartile (42%).
population_specificity: Non-pregnant and non-lactating women of reproductive age in seven districts of the Mbeya region, Tanzania.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how riboflavin-related gene expression contributes to enhanced electron transfer and wastewater degradation efficiency in microbial communities.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin gene expression was up-regulated in electroactive microorganisms, enhancing electron transfer and improving wastewater degradation efficiency. The micro-electric field structure facilitated this process, confirming riboflavin's role in microbial electron transfer.
population_specificity: Microbial communities in kitchen-oil wastewater.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate riboflavin's role as an exfoliation agent in producing molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) nanosheets for bone tissue engineering scaffolds.
results_summary: Riboflavin-assisted MoS2 nanosheets (RF-MoS2) were successfully integrated into alginate-chitosan scaffolds, which demonstrated biocompatibility, enhanced alkaline phosphatase activity, and promoted mineralization in bone tissue engineering applications.
population_specificity: In vitro study using C3H10T1/2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the biomechanical effects of corneal cross-linking (CXL) using riboflavin solutions with different osmolarities on rabbit corneas, particularly for thin corneas below the safe thickness threshold.
results_summary: The study found that CXL with hypotonic riboflavin solutions improved corneal biomechanical stiffness (tangent modulus) compared to controls, but no significant differences were observed between different hydration levels. The stromal demarcation line depth varied among CXL groups, but the relative depth ratio to total corneal thickness did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Rabbit corneas

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy and safety of trans-epithelial accelerated corneal collagen cross-linking (using Riboflavin) in halting the progression of keratoconus.
results_summary: The study found that 94.44% of patients showed no progression of keratoconus after 6 months, with 44.44% experiencing improved vision. The procedure was deemed safe with fewer complications than standard protocols.
population_specificity: Young patients (mean age 19.16±3.53 years) with keratoconus, particularly those associated with vernal keratoconjunctivitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal concentration and infiltration time of rose bengal (Rb) for achieving effective scleral crosslinking in rabbit eyes.
results_summary: The study found that increasing Rb infiltration time and concentration improved penetration depth and crosslinking efficacy, with the 0.5% Rb-10min group showing the highest biomechanical stiffness and resistance to enzyme digestion. No morphological differences were observed between treated and untreated groups, but Rb increased the diameter of large collagen fibers in the sclera.
population_specificity: Fresh rabbit eyes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and adverse events of riboflavin-PDT versus ALA-PDT in treating mild to moderate facial acne.
results_summary: Riboflavin-PDT showed comparable efficacy to ALA-PDT in reducing acne lesions, with significantly fewer adverse events such as pain, erythema, hyperpigmentation, and desquamation. The difference in improvement rates between the two treatments was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: 30 patients with mild to moderate facial acne.
effective_dosage: Not specified (3 sessions of PDT at 1-week intervals).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Riboflavin (Vitamin B2) supplementation could improve climbing ability in Drosophila melanogaster Appld mutants.
results_summary: Riboflavin supplementation, along with vitamin C, improved climbing ability in Appld mutants, suggesting a potential role in mitigating motor deficits. No adverse effects or toxicity were reported.
population_specificity: Drosophila melanogaster (fruit flies) with Appl null mutations.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify functional properties, including riboflavin biosynthesis genes, in L. plantarum strains to assess their probiotic potential.
results_summary: The study identified genes required for riboflavin biosynthesis in L. plantarum strains, suggesting their potential to produce riboflavin, but did not measure actual riboflavin production or its effects.
population_specificity: L. plantarum strains isolated from Ethiopian traditional cottage cheese.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the corneal biomechanical effects of FS-LASIK combined with accelerated corneal crosslinking (LASIK Xtra, using Riboflavin) versus conventional FS-LASIK in highly myopic eyes.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in corneal biomechanical response between LASIK Xtra (with Riboflavin) and conventional LASIK 12 months postoperatively, indicating no protective stiffening effect from Riboflavin-enhanced crosslinking.
population_specificity: 19 patients (38 eyes) with high myopia (-7.34 ± 1.02 diopters).
effective_dosage: 30mW/cm² UV-A for 90 seconds (Riboflavin dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a sensitive sensor for detecting riboflavin concentration using a dual-peak long period fiber grating (DP-LPFG) coated with β-cyclodextrin-doped silica-based materials.
results_summary: The sensor demonstrated high sensitivity with a detection limit of 0.08 nM, a response time under 3 minutes, and excellent repeatability and selectivity, making it promising for applications in disease treatment, diagnosis, and food quality assurance.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro sensor study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare different excitation methods for tracking cellular metabolism using auto-fluorescent coenzymes NAD(P)H and FAD in living cancer cells, particularly in response to doxorubicin treatment.
results_summary: The study found that single 800 nm excitation of both coenzymes was advantageous for metabolic imaging, and machine-learning models provided the most statistically robust results for detecting early drug response. All three analysis methods (FLIRR, PCA, and AE) led to similar biological conclusions regarding redox state changes.
population_specificity: Living cancer cells (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of Cytoflavin (which contains Riboflavin) in improving speech and reducing disability in patients with acute ischemic stroke (AIS) when combined with speech therapy.
results_summary: Patients receiving Cytoflavin showed significantly lower disability levels, better speech communication (mean GKS score 3 vs. 2), and greater regression of aphasia compared to the control group. The combination of Cytoflavin, speech therapy, and physical rehabilitation yielded clinically meaningful improvements.
population_specificity: 46 right-handed patients hospitalized during the acute phase of AIS in the left middle cerebral artery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the presentation, treatment, and outcomes of patients with molecularly confirmed riboflavin transporter deficiency (formerly BVVL syndrome).
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin transporter deficiencies cause sensorimotor axonal neuropathy and cranial neuropathy, presenting with weakness, hearing loss, and respiratory difficulties. Oral riboflavin supplementation was lifesaving, and treatment should begin immediately upon suspicion without awaiting molecular confirmation.
population_specificity: Patients with molecularly confirmed riboflavin transporter deficiency (RFVT2 or RFVT3 mutations).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore riboflavin's global status, its interaction with the MTHFR C677T polymorphism, and its potential role in personalized nutrition, particularly in modulating blood pressure.
results_summary: Riboflavin supplementation significantly reduced systolic blood pressure by 5-13 mmHg in adults with the MTHFR 677TT genotype, suggesting a novel role in hypertension management for genetically at-risk individuals. However, further studies are needed to assess higher doses and broader populations.
population_specificity: Adults with the MTHFR 677TT genotype, particularly in the UK, Irish, and other global populations where this polymorphism is prevalent.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of riboflavin-assisted corneal crosslinking (SMILE Xtra) in preventing keratectasia in high-risk patients with thin corneas or borderline topography.
results_summary: Riboflavin-assisted crosslinking combined with SMILE Xtra showed stable refractive outcomes, improved uncorrected visual acuity, and no keratectasia progression over 12 months, though transient corneal edema occurred postoperatively.
population_specificity: 53 patients (105 eyes) with myopia and elevated keratectasia risk per Randleman criteria.
effective_dosage: Not specified (riboflavin solution introduced into corneal pocket).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of rice protein peptides (RPP) on alcoholic liver disease (ALD) in mice, focusing on gut microbiota and liver metabolites.
results_summary: RPP significantly alleviated ALD symptoms, including adiposity, oxidative stress, and inflammation, by downregulating the PPARγ signaling pathway and fatty acid biosynthesis genes. It also improved gut microbiota dysbiosis and increased short-chain fatty acids.
population_specificity: Mice with alcoholic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review existing evidence on the effects of riboflavin (vitamin B2) supplementation for migraine prophylaxis in adults and children.
results_summary: The study found that riboflavin supplementation in adults reduced the frequency and duration of migraine attacks with no serious side effects, but evidence was insufficient to recommend it as adjunct therapy for children.
population_specificity: Adults and children with migraines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how enzyme hydrolysis-assisted fibrillation dual modification affects the solubility, emulsifying properties, and antioxidant activity of rice protein.
results_summary: The modified rice proteins (RPH, RPN, RPHN) showed improved solubility, antioxidant activity, and emulsifying capacity, with RPHN performing best. RPHN also demonstrated high emulsion stability and no cytotoxicity to human cell lines.
population_specificity: Human cell lines (in vitro study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rice protein peptide (RPP) could protect against DSS-induced inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) and associated cognitive impairment and depression symptoms, and to explore its underlying neurobiological mechanisms.
results_summary: RPP treatment in DSS-induced mice improved body weight, colon length, intestinal barrier function, and behavioral performance. It enhanced phenylalanine and tyrosine metabolism, upregulated key brain metabolites, and activated the BDNF/TrkB/CREB signaling pathway, suggesting potential benefits for IBD-related cognitive and depressive symptoms.
population_specificity: DSS-induced colitis mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze how rice protein hydrolysates (RPHs) affect the physicochemical properties, structure, and starch digestibility of extruded rice starch-protein hydrolysate complexes.
results_summary: RPHs significantly increased resistant starch content, hindered starch digestibility through enzyme inhibition and structural interactions, and improved thermal stability. Higher hydrolysis degrees in RPHs showed greater inhibition of starch digestibility and reinforced the V-type crystalline structure.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro or model system study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a method using gluconic acid (GA) rinsing to reduce cadmium (Cd) contamination in rice protein while evaluating its impact on structural and functional properties.
results_summary: GA rinsing effectively removed 96.0% and 93.6% of Cd from rice protein-H and rice protein-L, respectively, without significantly altering structural properties. It also improved foaming properties, water holding capacity, and oil holding capacity.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on rice protein samples).
effective_dosage: Liquid-solid ratio of 30 mL/g, oscillation time of 120 min.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of pH-shifting treatments on the emulsifying properties of rice protein isolates (RPI).
results_summary: Alkaline pH-shifting treatment improved RPI's emulsifying properties, resulting in smaller emulsion particle size, more uniform distribution, and higher emulsifying activity and stability. The treatment promoted protein rearrangement and increased glutelin-type isoforms at the oil-water interface.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the solubility of rice protein (RP) using ultrasound-assisted glycation with dextran to enhance its industrial application in food products.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound-assisted glycation significantly increased RP solubility to 90.6%, improved foaming and emulsifying properties, and altered protein structure by reducing β-sheets and increasing random coils. The method was more efficient than traditional wet-heating glycation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to improve the solubility and surface activity of rice protein isolates (RPI) using combined pH-shifting, ultrasound, and heat treatments.
results_summary: The combined treatments significantly increased protein solubility (from ~2.7% to ~91.8%) and surface hydrophobicity (up to ~283%), resulting in less compact protein aggregates and improved emulsion stability compared to untreated RPI.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on commercial RPI)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of rice protein (RP) on acute colitis induced by dextran sulfate sodium (DSS) in mice and investigate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: RP treatment alleviated colitis symptoms, repaired colonic function, regulated inflammatory factors, restored oxidative balance, activated the Keap1-Nrf2 signaling pathway, and modulated gut microbiota and short-chain fatty acid levels in mice.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced acute colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the protective effects of industrially produced rice protein peptides (RPP) on dextran sulfate sodium (DSS)-induced acute colitis in mice and the potential mechanisms.
results_summary: RPP treatment alleviated colitis symptoms in mice, including weight loss and colon injury, regulated inflammatory and oxidative balance, activated the Keap1-Nrf2 signaling pathway, and improved gut microbiota composition and intestinal barrier function.
population_specificity: Mice with DSS-induced acute colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the in vitro digestion behavior of rice protein isolate (RPI) and its blend with pea protein isolate (PPI), focusing on how heating affects their structuring and breakdown.
results_summary: Rice protein isolate (RPI) showed low solubility regardless of heating, and rice prolamins resisted hydrolysis by digestive enzymes. In blends with pea protein, rice protein hindered pea protein aggregation during digestion.
population_specificity: In vitro study (no human or animal subjects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of heat treatment on protein interaction, surface hydrophobicity, amino acid composition, and in vitro digestibility of individual rice protein fractions.
results_summary: Heat treatment at 100°C for 20 minutes did not negatively affect essential amino acids but increased surface hydrophobicity and decreased free-thiol content. Digestibility remained unaffected for glutelin, globulin, and albumin but may have been reduced for prolamin due to intramolecular disulfide bonds and hydrophobic interactions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rice protein coatings enriched with essential oils in maintaining the interior quality of fresh eggs during storage.
results_summary: Rice protein coatings, especially when enriched with essential oils, significantly reduced weight loss and preserved egg quality (Haugh unit, yolk index, and pH) for up to 6 weeks compared to uncoated eggs. The coatings extended shelf life by up to 3 weeks longer than uncoated eggs.
population_specificity: Fresh eggs stored at 20°C.
effective_dosage: 8% rice protein concentrate, enriched with 1% essential oils (tea tree, copaíba, or thymo).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether ultrasound treatment could improve the film-forming properties of rice protein hydrolysates (RPH) when combined with chitosan (CS) for edible composite films.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment significantly improved the mechanical properties of RPH/CS films, increasing elongation at break by 125% at 400 W and reducing the peroxide value of soybean oil from 16.99 to 2.23 meq/kg. The treatment also enhanced film smoothness and compatibility, with hydrogen bonds and covalent interactions identified as key forces in film formation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on film properties)
effective_dosage: Not specified (ultrasonic power levels of 200 W and 400 W used)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a combination of rhamnolipid biosurfactant and F127/PAA hydrogels could effectively remove cadmium from contaminated rice protein while preserving its main components and structure.
results_summary: The two-step washing process removed 92% of cadmium from rice protein, reducing residual cadmium below safety levels (<0.2 mg/kg) without damaging the protein's structure. The combination of rhamnolipids and hydrogels showed a synergistic effect, as neither alone was effective in cadmium removal.
population_specificity: Contaminated rice protein (in vitro study, no human or animal subjects).
effective_dosage: Not specified (study describes a two-step washing process).
study_duration: Not specified (experimental procedure, no duration mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the suitability of hydrolyzed rice protein formulas (HRPFs) as a plant-based alternative for treating cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA) in infants and toddlers.
results_summary: HRPFs were found to be adequate for treating CMPA, supporting satisfactory growth in infants and toddlers, including those with CMPA. They serve as an alternative when cow's milk protein-based formulas are poorly tolerated or ineffective.
population_specificity: Infants and toddlers aged 0-3 years, including those with cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rice protein coatings, with and without propolis, in maintaining the interior quality and shell strength of fresh eggs during storage at 20°C for 6 weeks.
results_summary: Coated eggs (rice protein alone or with propolis at 5% or 10%) showed significantly better quality metrics (Haugh unit, yolk index, weight loss) compared to uncoated eggs. Scanning electron microscopy confirmed reduced surface porosity in coated eggs, suggesting a protective barrier against gas and moisture transfer.
population_specificity: Fresh eggs stored at room temperature.
effective_dosage: Rice protein concentrate with propolis at 5% or 10%.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of rice protein coatings in maintaining the interior quality and eggshell strength of fresh eggs during storage compared to mineral oil and uncoated controls.
results_summary: Rice protein coatings (5%, 10%, and 15%) significantly reduced weight loss and preserved internal egg quality (Haugh unit, yolk index, pH) for up to 4 weeks longer than uncoated eggs, though mineral oil performed slightly better. Scanning electron microscopy confirmed reduced surface porosity in coated eggs, suggesting a protective barrier against gas and moisture transfer.
population_specificity: Fresh eggs stored at 20°C.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of lysine supplementation on the growth performance of blunt snout bream when fish meal was replaced by rice protein concentrate, and to characterize the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Fish fed rice protein concentrate (RPC) without lysine showed poorer growth performance and shorter intestinal villi compared to those fed fish meal or RPC with lysine. Lysine supplementation restored growth performance and influenced gene expressions related to growth pathways, suggesting its role in mediating growth effects in FM-free diets.
population_specificity: Blunt snout bream (Megalobrama amblycephala)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a rice protein matrix could enhance the bioavailability of xanthohumol (XN) and its metabolites after oral consumption in humans.
results_summary: The study found that plasma concentrations of XN and its metabolites were significantly higher when consumed with a spent hops-rice protein matrix compared to a control spent hops preparation, indicating enhanced bioavailability.
population_specificity: Healthy participants (n = 6)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if direct steam injection (DSI) processing with pH adjustment could enhance the functional properties of pea-rice protein isolate blends.
results_summary: The study found that DSI processing at 107°C and pH 11 significantly improved solubility, emulsifying activity, foam stability, and oil holding capacity of the protein blend without reducing available lysine or altering essential amino acid composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on protein blends)
effective_dosage: 5% (w/w) protein slurry, pea-rice protein ratio of 2:1 (w/w)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of rice prolamin on anti-tumor immune response in vitro and leukemia growth in vivo.
results_summary: Prolamin-enriched rice fractions inhibited leukemia cell viability and promoted anti-tumor immunity in mice, reducing tumor weight and increasing cytokine levels without significant toxicity.
population_specificity: Syngeneic L1210-bearing DBA/2 mice and human leukemia Jurkat cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to establish a new model to reflect the real ultrasound pretreatment process on rice protein and evaluate its effects on yield and enzymatic hydrolysis efficiency.
results_summary: Ultrasound treatment significantly increased the yield of soluble rice protein and improved enzymatic hydrolysis efficiency, but excessive ultrasonic power density and temperature caused protein aggregation. A modified kinetic model was developed to account for these effects, and SEM results showed structural changes influencing hydrolysis efficiency.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of ultrasound-assisted α-amylase degradation (UAD) treatment in improving the extraction rate, purity, and functional properties of rice protein (RP) from rice dreg powder.
results_summary: UAD treatment significantly increased protein extraction rate (89.58%) and purity (92.99%) compared to traditional methods, while also improving solubility, emulsifying activity, and foaming capacity of the extracted protein. The treatment altered protein structure without changing the main peptide chain or amino acid composition.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on rice dreg powder)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to isolate highly purified proteins from rice syrup meal and examine their hepatoprotective effects in vitro and in vivo.
results_summary: SRP70, derived from rice syrup meal, demonstrated hepatoprotective effects by reducing cytotoxicity and oxidative stress markers in hepatocytes and mice, while enhancing antioxidant enzyme activities. These effects were dose-dependent and supported by gene expression changes and histopathological evidence.
population_specificity: Rat primary hepatocytes and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how alkali treatment during rice protein extraction affects its antioxidant activity.
results_summary: The study found that higher alkali concentrations (e.g., 0.4% NaOH) reduced rice protein's antioxidant capacity, including radical-scavenging, metal chelating, and reducing power, particularly after gastrointestinal digestion.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism of solubilization of rice protein isolates (RPIs) using freeze-milling combined with alkali pretreatment to enhance commercial availability.
results_summary: Freeze-milling combined with alkali pretreatment increased soluble RPIs by up to 42 times, with structural analyses showing protein unfolding, disrupted hydrophobic surfaces, and exposed hydrophilic groups. The technique also led to disaggregation and strong water-protein interactions, indicating its potential for food industry applications.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory study on rice protein isolates)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of replacing fishmeal with rice protein concentrate (RPC) supplemented with xylooligosaccharides (XOS) on growth performance, antioxidant capability, and immune response in blunt snout bream.
results_summary: RPC alone reduced growth performance compared to fishmeal, but supplementation with 1.5% XOS significantly improved growth, antioxidant activity, immune response, and resistance to Aeromonas hydrophila infection.
population_specificity: Blunt snout bream (Megalobrama amblycephala) with an initial weight of 46.85 ± 0.34 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical tolerance and growth outcomes of extensively hydrolysed rice protein infant formula (eRHF) in infants with confirmed cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA).
results_summary: All 39 infants tolerated the eRHF without adverse effects and exhibited normal growth over the study period, supporting its use as an alternative to cow's milk-based formulas for CMPA.
population_specificity: Infants aged 0.5-6 months diagnosed with cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the hypo-allergenicity and safety of extensively hydrolyzed rice protein infant formula (eRHF) as an alternative for infants with cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA).
results_summary: The eRHF was well-tolerated by all infants, significantly reducing symptom-based scores within the first month and supporting catch-up growth to normal weight gain and normalization of growth parameters over the 6-month study period.
population_specificity: Infants (mean age 3.4 months, range 1-6 months) with confirmed cow's milk protein allergy (CMPA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether transglutaminase (TGase) and rice protein isolate (RPI) could improve the properties of rice dough and the quality of gluten-free rice noodles.
results_summary: The study found that TGase increased the storage and loss moduli of rice dough, while RPI decreased them, but the combined RPI+TGase treatment restored these properties to control levels. The treatment also improved viscosity parameters, reduced cooking loss and water turbidity, and smoothed the noodle surface.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or food product testing, not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a process for recovering highly concentrated protein and phosphorus compounds from rice bran without using enzymes or harsh chemicals.
results_summary: The study achieved high protein content (52.3% w/w) and efficient phosphorus recovery (15.1-16.4% w/w P) from rice bran, with no detected heavy metal ions in the final fractions. The process demonstrated practical feasibility for industrial application.
population_specificity: Not specified (laboratory-scale study on rice bran material).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare two methods of processing rice protein (alkaline extraction vs. starch degradation) to determine which improves digestibility for food manufacturing applications.
results_summary: Alkaline-extracted rice protein (AE-RP) showed higher digestibility than starch-degraded rice protein (SD-RP), attributed to structural changes in protein bodies (PB-I and PB-II) caused by alkali treatment. AE-RP had a higher crude protein content (84.7%) compared to SD-RP (78.2%), with similar amino acid compositions except for lower cysteine and methionine in AE-RP.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize rice proteins by analyzing their molecular properties, amino-acid sequences, glycosylation status, and disulphide bonding.
results_summary: The study identified and sequenced N-terminal and internal amino-acid regions of rice proteins, determined glycosylation and disulphide bonding status, and compiled a data-file of rice protein properties.
population_specificity: Rice proteins from embryos, endosperms, and leaves.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical tolerance and safety of a hydrolysed rice protein formula (HRPF) versus an extensively hydrolysed cow's milk protein formula (EHF) in infants with IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy.
results_summary: The HRPF was well tolerated, with no allergic reactions reported, and infants showed similar growth and clinical tolerance development compared to those on EHF. The HRPF was tolerated by over 90% of infants, suggesting it is a safe and effective alternative to cow's milk-based formulas.
population_specificity: Infants (mean age 4.3 months, range 1.1-10.1 months) diagnosed with IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacological properties of aspalathin (ASP) from rooibos in alleviating atopic dermatitis (AD) by examining local and systemic immune responses.
results_summary: Topical ASP significantly reduced AD symptoms in mice, including erythema, scaling, and skin thickening, while lowering inflammatory markers and immune cell infiltration. ASP also suppressed allergy- and inflammation-linked cytokines in T cells, basophils, and keratinocytes by inhibiting STAT6 and NFAT1 activation.
population_specificity: AD mouse model

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential neuroprotective effects of Rooibos and its major flavonoids on Alzheimer's disease mechanisms, including oxidative stress, tau protein, amyloid plaques, inflammation, and metal toxicity.
results_summary: The study reviewed literature suggesting Rooibos may modulate neurodegenerative mechanisms linked to Alzheimer's disease, but it did not present new experimental data or definitive clinical outcomes. The abstract implies potential benefits but lacks conclusive efficacy results.
population_specificity: Not specified (literature review, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefit of acute administration of unfermented rooibos on vascular health in a larval zebrafish model of stroke.
results_summary: Rooibos treatment limited thrombus formation, prevented stroke-induced deficits in larval motility, reduced lipid peroxidation, normalized neuronal protein expression, and improved tight junction protein levels, suggesting neuroprotective and vascular-protective effects.
population_specificity: Larval zebrafish model of stroke.
effective_dosage: Not specified (aqueous solution of an ethanolic extract of unfermented Rooibos).
study_duration: 24-hour ponatinib exposure with concurrent rooibos treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Rooibos on cardiovascular function in individuals at risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) using echocardiography.
results_summary: The study found that Rooibos consumption led to some improvements in cardiovascular function, such as reduced left atrium size and interventricular septum diameter, with fermented Rooibos also decreasing left ventricle mass. However, no significant changes were observed in aorta dimensions or left ventricle posterior wall.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk of cardiovascular disease (CVD) in South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate existing human intervention studies on rooibos tea to assess its health benefits and identify gaps in the literature.
results_summary: Rooibos tea was found to improve lipid profiles, enhance antioxidant status, and lower blood glucose levels in both healthy and at-risk individuals, though results were inconsistent due to varying dosages and types of tea.
population_specificity: Participants aged 6 to 83 years, including healthy individuals and those at risk or diagnosed with chronic conditions.
effective_dosage: 200 to 1,200 ml of fermented, unfermented, or black rooibos tea.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to illustrate the challenges in progressing ethnomedicines like rooibos to official treatment regimens in low-to-middle-income countries, focusing on regulatory hurdles and research biases.
results_summary: The study highlights the high standard of ethnomedicine research in Africa, particularly for rooibos, but notes potential biases in preclinical focus and the need for independent clinical trial coordination. It does not provide specific efficacy results for rooibos.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on ethnomedicine research in Africa, particularly South Africa).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rooibos on intestinal health, specifically its potential to improve gastrointestinal integrity and functionality, using larval zebrafish models.
results_summary: Aqueous and ethanol extracts of green rooibos rescued TNBS-induced intestinal damage, reduced oxidative and inflammatory markers, and normalized tight junction protein expression. The aqueous extract also improved gastrointestinal motility dysregulation.
population_specificity: Larval zebrafish
effective_dosage: 2 mg/ml aqueous extract of green rooibos

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of aspalathin (ASP), a flavonoid in rooibos, on mast cell-mediated allergic inflammation using in vivo and in vitro models.
results_summary: ASP dose-dependently suppressed IgE-mediated allergic responses, including reduced mast cell degranulation, histamine secretion, and pro-inflammatory cytokine production, outperforming nothofagin. It inhibited key signaling pathways (FcεRI, Lyn, Fyn, Syk) and transcription factors (NFAT, NF-κB).
population_specificity: Mouse models (PCA and ASA) and mast cell lines (RBL-2H3 and mouse bone marrow-derived mast cells).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effect of inorganic fertilization and soil depth on soil water dynamics and rooibos plant growth under drought conditions.
results_summary: The study found that unfertilized rooibos plants on deeper soils had higher shoot biomass and longer taproots due to better soil water retention, while fertilized plants showed lower biomass due to high phosphorus concentration. Rooibos plants survived drought through an adapted root system and a proposed moisture-harvesting mechanism in the upper soil layers.
population_specificity: Young rooibos plantation at Nardouwsberg, Western Cape, South Africa.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rooibos tea extract could inhibit PGE2 formation and the expression of related enzymes (cPLA2, COX-2, mPGES-1) in human monocytes, compared to green and black tea extracts.
results_summary: Rooibos tea extract inhibited LPS and calcium ionophore-induced PGE2 formation, though with lower potency than green and black tea. It also inhibited LPS-induced mPGES-1 expression but had minimal effects on COX-2 and cPLA2 expression.
population_specificity: Human monocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combined effects of an aspalathin-rich green rooibos extract (GRT) with glyburide and atorvastatin on glycemia, dyslipidemia, and liver lipid accumulation in a type 2 diabetic mouse model.
results_summary: The study found that combining GRT with glyburide and atorvastatin enhanced the hypotriglyceridemic effect of atorvastatin and reduced lipid droplet accumulation in the liver. However, GRT alone or with glyburide did not affect blood glucose or lipid profiles but still reduced lipid droplet accumulation.
population_specificity: Male type 2 diabetic (db/db) mice and their nondiabetic lean db+ littermates.
effective_dosage: 100 mg/kg bodyweight of GRT, 5 mg/kg bodyweight of glyburide, and 80 mg/kg bodyweight of atorvastatin.
interactions: Enhanced hypotriglyceridemic effect when GRT was combined with glyburide and atorvastatin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether flavonoids in rooibos tea (aspalathin, isoorientin, and orientin) could improve mitochondrial function in C2C12 myotubes under conditions of induced dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found that rooibos flavonoids reversed mitochondrial dysfunction caused by antimycin A, reduced reactive oxygen species production, and enhanced the expression of genes related to mitochondrial function, performing comparably to metformin and insulin.
population_specificity: C2C12 myotubes (a preclinical cell model).
effective_dosage: 10 µM of aspalathin, isoorientin, and orientin.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and hepatic activity of Rooibos tea, including its antioxidative, anti-mutagenic properties, and potential herb-drug interactions.
results_summary: Rooibos exhibits antioxidative and anti-mutagenic properties and modulates microsomal enzymes. While rodent studies show protective or neutral effects on liver function, some human case reports suggest possible acute hepatic damage, with contamination potentially contributing to liver injury.
population_specificity: Preclinical (in vitro and rodent) and human studies, including case reports.
interactions: Possible herb-drug interactions due to impact on CYPs, affecting bioavailability of co-administered medicines.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of rooibos in improving insulin signaling in the testicular tissue of type I diabetic rats.
results_summary: Rooibos (DRF group) showed an acute upregulation in IRS-1 protein expression but a decrease in PkB/Akt compared to diabetic controls, suggesting partial improvement in insulin signaling pathways.
population_specificity: Type I diabetic rats (STZ-induced).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of Rooibos-derived compounds (linearthin, aspalathin, and nothofagin) to protect skin cells from UVB-induced oxidative stress and damage.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with Rooibos compounds (linearthin, aspalathin, and nothofagin) at low concentrations protected skin cells (HaCaT and SK-MEL-1) from UVB-induced damage, improving cell viability and metabolic activity while reducing oxidative stress markers. Linearthin showed the highest cytoprotective effects, with IC50 values indicating strong efficacy.
population_specificity: In vitro study using HaCaT (keratinocytes) and SK-MEL-1 (melanocytes) skin cell lines.
effective_dosage: IC50 values: linearthin (282 µg/mL for HaCaT, 248.3-142.6 µg/mL for SK-MEL-1), aspalathin (398.9 µg/mL for HaCaT).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of combining an aspalathin-rich green rooibos extract (GRT) with pioglitazone and atorvastatin on blood glucose and lipid levels in obese diabetic mice.
results_summary: The combination of GRT, pioglitazone, and atorvastatin effectively lowered fasting plasma glucose and triglyceride levels, while atorvastatin monotherapy reduced cholesterol and LDL-C. However, gene expression changes suggested potential hepatotoxic effects when GRT was combined with atorvastatin.
population_specificity: Obese diabetic (db/db) mice and their nondiabetic lean littermate controls (db+).
effective_dosage: GRT (100 mg/kg daily), pioglitazone (25 mg/kg daily), atorvastatin (80 mg/kg daily).
interactions: Enhanced hypotriglyceridemic effect when GRT was combined with pioglitazone and atorvastatin; cholesterol levels affected when GRT was combined with atorvastatin alone.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardioprotective effects of aspalathin-rich green rooibos (GRT) on obesity-induced cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors in obese Wistar rats.
results_summary: GRT supplementation significantly alleviated obesity-induced CVD risk factors, including high blood pressure, impaired vasodilation, reduced antioxidant enzyme activity, and elevated oxidative stress markers. The extract also improved the expression of key cell-signaling proteins (eNOS, AMPK, and PKB) in aortic tissues.
population_specificity: Obese male Wistar rats fed a high-fat diet.
