study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of rooibos to mitigate FB1-induced toxicity, particularly its role in combating mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS generation.
results_summary: The study suggests that rooibos, due to its antioxidant and bioactive properties, may protect against FB1-induced cellular damage by addressing mitochondrial dysfunction and ROS overproduction. It highlights rooibos as a socio-economically viable intervention for FB1 toxicoses.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on vulnerable populations in developing countries)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the cardioprotective potential of Afriplex green rooibos extract against ischemia/reperfusion injury in rats with cardiovascular disease and metabolic dysfunction.
results_summary: Afriplex green rooibos extract reduced infarct size, improved heart function, lowered inflammation, and decreased oxidative stress in high-caloric diet rats. It also modulated key metabolic and stress signaling pathways, enhancing cardioprotection during ischemia/reperfusion.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats fed a high-caloric diet to induce prediabetes and cardiovascular disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the combinatory cardioprotective effects of rooibos compounds (aspalathin and PPAG) against hyperglycemia-induced cardiac damage and compare them to metformin.
results_summary: The combination of rooibos compounds improved myocardial substrate metabolism, maintained mitochondrial membrane potential, reduced oxidative stress markers, and showed superior DNA damage protection compared to metformin. The study suggests rooibos compounds have unique cardioprotective properties against hyperglycemia-induced cardiac damage.
population_specificity: H9c2 cardiomyocytes exposed to chronic high glucose concentrations (in vitro model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fermented and unfermented rooibos could counteract the harmful vascular and pro-oxidant effects of nicotine in rats.
results_summary: Fermented rooibos (RF) and melatonin (Mel) improved vascular function and increased antioxidant enzyme activity in nicotine-exposed rats, while unfermented rooibos (RUF) showed anti-contractile effects. RF also increased nitric oxide production in nicotine-exposed endothelial cells.
population_specificity: Male adult rats and rat aortic endothelial cells (AECs).
effective_dosage: 2% RF, 2% RUF, or 4% Mel co-administered with nicotine (5 mg/kg body weight/day). RF pre-treatment in AECs: 0.015 mg/ml.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism by which rooibos extract (RE) alleviates symptoms of dryness (sicca syndrome) and its effects on saliva and tear secretion.
results_summary: RE significantly increased tear and saliva volumes in mice in a dose-dependent manner, and its effects were mediated via the muscarinic acetylcholine receptor 3 (M3R).
population_specificity: Wild-type C57BL/6 (B6) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the pharmacokinetics and distribution of E6CG, the active component in rooibos extract, in exocrine glands of mice and its potential to improve systemic dryness.
results_summary: The study found that E6CG from rooibos extract was absorbed into blood plasma, peaked at 19.3 minutes post-administration, and was detected in various exocrine glands, suggesting its potential to improve dryness. Rooibos extracts containing E6CG may serve as functional foods for addressing systemic dryness.
population_specificity: C57BL/6 mice and implied human relevance (based on prior findings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an aspalathin-rich green rooibos extract (GRT) exhibits anti-cancer activity against castration-resistant prostate cancer (CRPC) cells.
results_summary: GRT suppressed the proliferation and survival of CRPC cells, induced apoptosis, and inhibited tumor growth in a xenograft mouse model by targeting Akt signaling pathways.
population_specificity: CRPC cells (LNCaP 104-R1, LNCaP FGC, PC-3) and castrated nude mice with LNCaP 104-R1 xenografts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the histological effects of an aspalathin-rich green rooibos extract (GRE) on liver steatosis, inflammation, and body weight in a diet-induced obese rat model.
results_summary: GRE co-treatment significantly reduced body and liver mass, steatosis area, inflammation, and hepatocellular injury in high-fat diet-fed rats, suggesting anti-steatotic, anti-inflammatory, and weight-reducing effects.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (N=28) on a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rooibos extracts (fermented and green) could protect human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) from oxidative stress and inflammation induced by diesel exhaust particles.
results_summary: Pre-treatment with Rooibos extracts attenuated DEP-induced oxidative stress markers (ROS, protein carbonyls, lipid peroxidation) and inflammatory cytokine expression, while enhancing antioxidant gene expression (NQO1, Nrf2) and cell viability. The effects were comparable to those of the flavone orientin.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) in vitro.
effective_dosage: 40 and 60 µg/ml of fermented (FR) and green (GR) Rooibos extracts.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aqueous rooibos extract (RE) could mitigate the cardiovascular toxicity induced by diesel exhaust particles (DEP) in Wistar rats.
results_summary: Rooibos extract significantly attenuated DEP-induced oxidative stress, inflammation, and gene expression changes in the aorta and heart, including reductions in MDA, CDs, pro-inflammatory cytokines (IL-8, TNFα, IL-1β), and NF-κB signaling, while restoring anti-inflammatory IL-10 and IκB levels. It also modulated Nrf2 and HO-1 mRNA levels, suggesting protective effects against DEP toxicity.
population_specificity: Wistar rats exposed to DEP

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether aspalathin-rich Rooibos extract (GRT™) could modulate atorvastatin (ATV)-induced hepatotoxicity in C3A liver cells under palmitate-treated conditions.
results_summary: The study found that GRT did not ameliorate ATV-induced hepatotoxic effects, including increased ROS production and apoptosis, in palmitate-treated C3A liver cells. Combination therapy of GRT + ATV also showed significant increases in ROS production.
population_specificity: C3A liver cells cultured with and without palmitate.
interactions: Interaction with atorvastatin (ATV) noted, showing no protective effect against ATV-induced hepatotoxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether an aspalathin-enriched green rooibos extract (GRE) could ameliorate hepatic insulin resistance by improving insulin sensitivity through PI3K/AKT, FOXO1, and AMPK-mediated pathways.
results_summary: GRE attenuated palmitate-induced impairment of glucose and lipid metabolism in C3A liver cells and improved insulin sensitivity in obese insulin-resistant (OBIR) rats. It enhanced PI3K/AKT and AMPK phosphorylation, increased glucose transporter 2 expression, and stimulated genes involved in glucose and lipid metabolism.
population_specificity: C3A liver cells and obese insulin-resistant (OBIR) rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant activity and protective effects of Rooibos tea extract on liver mitochondria oxidative phosphorylation in rats with CCl4-induced liver damage.
results_summary: The study found that Rooibos tea extract significantly improved mitochondrial respiration, ATP production, and reduced oxidative stress in rats with liver damage. It also decreased elevated enzyme levels and improved histological features, suggesting antioxidant and membrane-stabilizing effects.
population_specificity: Rats with carbon tetrachloride-induced liver damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antidiabetic potential of Rooibos and its polyphenols in managing type 2 diabetes mellitus (T2DM).
results_summary: The study suggests that Rooibos and its bioactive compounds may offer therapeutic benefits for T2DM, though specific efficacy data are not detailed in the abstract. The review highlights the potential of Rooibos as a natural antioxidant source for diabetes management.
population_specificity: Not specified (general focus on type 2 diabetes mellitus).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Aspalathin (Aspt) and nothofagin (Not) from green rooibos could modulate renal functional damage in a mouse model of sepsis and elucidate the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Treatment with Aspt and Not reduced renal damage markers (BUN, creatinine, urine protein, LDH), inhibited NF-κB activation, decreased inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6), and enhanced antioxidant defenses (superoxide dismutase, glutathione peroxidase, catalase) in CLP-induced septic mice.
population_specificity: Mice with CLP-induced sepsis and renal damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspalathin, a compound from Rooibos, could improve the efficacy of metformin in treating diabetes-associated symptoms in a diabetic mouse model.
results_summary: The combination of metformin and aspalathin was more effective than metformin alone in reducing fasting plasma glucose levels, improving glucose tolerance, and lowering body weight and fat content in diabetic mice. High-dose aspalathin (130 mg/kg) showed better potential than metformin alone, while a low dose (13 mg/kg) had no effect.
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic (db/db) mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects of rooibos extracts and their polyphenols on blood glucose levels in diabetic rodent models through a meta-analysis of existing evidence.
results_summary: The study found that rooibos extracts, particularly those rich in the phenolic compound PPAG, significantly lowered blood glucose levels in diabetic rodents, with a pooled effect size of -0.89 (95% CI: -1.44 to -0.35). The effect varied based on the type of rooibos extract and treatment duration.
population_specificity: Diabetic rodent models (88 treated with rooibos extracts or polyphenols, 85 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic potential of fermented and aspalathin-enriched green rooibos in dermal wound healing using in vitro models.
results_summary: Fermented rooibos increased nitric oxide production and markers of classically activated macrophages, while green rooibos reduced cyclooxygenase-2 levels in diabetic wound models. Both extracts decreased reactive oxygen species and protected fibroblasts from cell death.
population_specificity: In vitro models (RAW 264.7 macrophages, human dermal fibroblasts, glycated gelatin for diabetic wounds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify chemical changes in the phenolic composition of rooibos during different fermentation stages and assess the significance of these changes using multivariate statistical methods.
results_summary: The study found that fermentation significantly affects the extract compositions of rooibos, with all three statistical methods (ANOVA-Simultaneous Component Analysis, ANOVA-Target Projection, and regularized MANOVA) agreeing on the significance but differing in interpretation.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study of rooibos plant material).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antioxidant properties of aspalathin in Rooibos and its potential role in improving metabolic syndrome, as well as its stability, bioavailability, and possible herb-drug interactions.
results_summary: The study found that aspalathin has antioxidant properties and may improve glucose and lipid metabolism, but its use is limited by poor stability, low bioavailability, and potential interference with certain chronic medications for hyperglycaemia and dyslipidaemia.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro and in vivo studies discussed, but no specific human population mentioned).
interactions: Potential interference with metabolism of certain chronic medications for hyperglycaemia and dyslipidaemia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cytoprotective effect of PPAG from rooibos on pancreatic beta cells exposed to acute cell stress, including streptozotocin-induced damage and fatty acid cytotoxicity.
results_summary: PPAG protected beta cells from apoptotic cell death in vivo and in vitro, preserved anti-apoptotic protein BCL2 expression, and showed protective effects against streptozotocin and palmitate-induced cytotoxicity in both mouse and human pancreatic cells.
population_specificity: Mice treated with streptozotocin, INS-1E beta cells, and human pancreatic islet cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antiseptic effects and mechanisms of aspalathin (Asp) and nothofagin (Not) from green rooibos against HMGB1-mediated septic responses in HUVECs and mice.
results_summary: Asp and Not effectively inhibited LPS-induced HMGB1 release and suppressed HMGB1-mediated septic responses, including hyperpermeability, leukocyte adhesion/migration, and proinflammatory protein activation. They also reduced TNF-α, IL-6, NF-κB, and ERK1/2 activation, suggesting potential therapeutic benefits for vascular inflammatory diseases.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory effects and mechanisms of aspalathin and nothofagin from green rooibos against LPS-mediated vascular inflammatory responses.
results_summary: Aspalathin and nothofagin inhibited LPS-induced barrier disruption, reduced expression of cell adhesion molecules, suppressed leukocyte migration, and decreased production of pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, IL-6) and activation of NF-κB and ERK1/2 pathways. These compounds also reduced LPS-induced lethal endotoxemia in mice.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rooibos, alone or combined with red palm oil (RPO), could mitigate LPS-induced inflammation and improve cardiac function in rats.
results_summary: Rooibos alone increased anti-inflammatory cytokine IL-10 in plasma but did not affect baseline cardiac function. Combined with RPO, it enhanced myocardial IL-10 production, suggesting synergistic anti-inflammatory effects in heart tissue.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats weighing 150-200 g

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of aqueous rooibos tea extract (RTE) and red palm oil (RPO) on sperm motility parameters in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: Rooibos tea extract (RTE) significantly improved sperm linearity (LIN) and wobble (WOB) in diabetic rats. Co-administration with RPO also showed beneficial effects on sperm motility parameters.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether aspalathin (Asp) and nothofagin (Not) from green rooibos could suppress high glucose-induced vascular inflammation in endothelial cells and mice.
results_summary: Asp and Not inhibited high glucose-induced vascular hyperpermeability, monocyte adhesion, expression of cell adhesion molecules, ROS formation, and NF-κB activation, suggesting potential benefits for diabetic complications.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein endothelial cells (HUVECs) and mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antioxidant effects of rooibos tea extract (RTE), red palm oil (RPO), and their combination in diabetic rats.
results_summary: RTE and RPO + RTE improved liver GPx and reduced plasma TBARS in diabetic rats, bringing levels close to normal. RTE alone and combined with RPO also enhanced liver SOD and plasma ORAC.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rooibos tea could attenuate immobilization-induced oxidative stress in an animal model.
results_summary: Rooibos tea significantly reduced oxidative stress markers, reversed stress-related metabolite increases, prevented lipid peroxidation, restored protein degradation, regulated glutathione metabolism, and modulated antioxidant enzyme activities.
population_specificity: Animal model (chronic restraint or immobilization stress)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of aspalathin (Asp) and nothofagin (Not) from green rooibos on EPCR shedding and related inflammatory and coagulation pathways.
results_summary: Asp and Not inhibited PMA-, TNF-α-, IL-1β-, and CLP-induced EPCR shedding, reduced TACE expression and activity, suppressed thrombin generation, and decreased phosphorylation of p38, ERK 1/2, and JNK. These results suggest Asp and Not have potential as anti-sEPCR shedding reagents.
population_specificity: Endothelial cells (HUVECs) and mice (CLP model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of compost and nonpathogenic Pythium taxa in suppressing damping-off caused by pathogenic oomycetes in rooibos nurseries.
results_summary: Compost showed variable efficacy in suppressing damping-off, with one batch controlling 60% of isolates and another 37%. Combining compost with nonpathogenic Pythium taxa significantly improved suppression of damping-off, even for isolates resistant to compost alone.
population_specificity: Rooibos (Aspalathus linearis) nurseries affected by pathogenic oomycetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the xanthine oxidase (XOD) inhibitory activity of an aspalathin-rich fraction (ARF) and purified aspalathin from rooibos, as well as their hypouricemic effects in hyperuricemic mice.
results_summary: The ARF and aspalathin demonstrated dose-dependent XOD inhibition, with IC50 values of 20.4 μg/mL (ARF) and 4.5 μg/mL (aspalathin). In hyperuricemic mice, both significantly reduced plasma uric acid levels in a dose-dependent manner, likely due to XOD inhibition.
population_specificity: Hyperuricemic mice induced by inosine-5'-monophosphate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rooibos tea improves sperm function due to its antioxidant properties and assess its effects on male reproductive health.
results_summary: Unfermented rooibos improved sperm concentration, viability, and motility, while fermented rooibos enhanced sperm vitality but increased spontaneous acrosome reaction. Prolonged exposure caused subtle structural changes in reproductive organs and potential liver/kidney effects.
population_specificity: Male rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effect of fermented rooibos hot water soluble solids on in vitro adipocyte differentiation and metabolism, focusing on its potential anti-obesity properties.
results_summary: Rooibos soluble solids inhibited intracellular lipid accumulation, reduced mRNA and protein expression of adipogenesis-related genes, and decreased leptin secretion without cytotoxicity. Higher concentrations increased ATP levels and basal glucose uptake.
population_specificity: In vitro 3T3-L1 adipocytes

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the potential of Rooibos extract as a complementary therapy for metabolic diseases, focusing on its polyphenol content and effects on lipid metabolism and hepatic steatosis.
results_summary: Rooibos extract significantly reduced serum cholesterol, triglycerides, and free fatty acids in hyperlipemic mice, prevented hepatic steatosis, and altered adipocyte size and number, likely through AMPK activation, but showed no effect on insulin resistance.
population_specificity: Hyperlipemic mice fed a Western-type diet.
effective_dosage: Not specified (extract contained 25% w/w total polyphenols).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of rooibos tea on postnatal development and egg production in aged Japanese quail, assessing its potential benefits on body weight and reproductive longevity.
results_summary: Rooibos tea affected body weight differently by sex, decreasing it in males and increasing it in females. It also reduced the decline in egg production in aged hens, suggesting a prolonged productive period.
population_specificity: Aged Japanese quail (Coturnix coturnix japonica)
study_duration: Up to 100 days for body weight effects; egg production assessed at 360 days of age

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of rooibos tea on liver regeneration and biochemical parameters in rats after carbon tetrachloride-induced liver damage.
results_summary: Rooibos tea reduced liver enzyme activity (aspartate aminotransferase, alanine aminotransferase) and bilirubin levels, increased plasma albumin, decreased tissue malondialdehyde, and reduced fibrotic tissue extent compared to the water-drinking group. All biochemical parameters normalized to healthy levels after 42 days of regeneration.
population_specificity: Rats with carbon tetrachloride-induced liver damage.
study_duration: Administered during the entire experiment and/or only during the regeneration phase (exact duration unclear).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of rooibos tea on preventing and treating oxidative stress in streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
results_summary: Rooibos tea significantly reduced advanced glycation end-products (AGEs) and malondialdehyde (MDA) in plasma and tissues, particularly in the lens, but did not affect diabetic status markers like glucose or glycated hemoglobin. The study concluded that rooibos tea partially prevents oxidative stress and may help protect against diabetic vascular complications.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced diabetic rats.
effective_dosage: Not specified (aqueous and alkaline extracts used).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of rooibos tea on liver antioxidant status and oxidative stress in a rat model of carbon tetrachloride-induced liver damage, comparing it to the synthetic antioxidant NAC.
results_summary: Rooibos tea restored liver concentrations of CoQ9H2 and alpha-tocopherol and inhibited lipid peroxidation (MDA formation) in CCl4-damaged rats, comparable to healthy animals, though it did not counteract the decrease in CoQ9. NAC outperformed rooibos in restoring CoQ9 levels.
population_specificity: Rats with carbon tetrachloride-induced liver damage.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rooibos tea extract could suppress X-ray-induced oncogenic transformation in mouse C3H10T1/2 cells.
results_summary: Rooibos tea extract significantly reduced X-ray-induced transformation in a dose- and time-dependent manner, with 10% concentration achieving transformation levels similar to spontaneous rates. Green tea extract at an equitoxic concentration showed no effect.
population_specificity: Mouse C3H10T1/2 cells (in vitro study).
study_duration: Entire incubation period (exact duration not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the antibacterial action and mechanism of rose essential oil (REO) against Aeromonas veronii isolated from Northern snakehead.
results_summary: REO demonstrated significant bacteriostatic activity against A. veronii, disrupting cellular morphology, increasing membrane permeability, and inducing leakage of intracellular biomolecules. Metabolomics analysis revealed REO disturbed key metabolic pathways, confirming its antibacterial effect.
population_specificity: Aeromonas veronii isolated from Northern snakehead.
effective_dosage: Minimum inhibitory concentration of 1.25 μl ml-1.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Rooibos tea (RT) suppresses chromosome aberrations and micronuclei induced by mutagens like benzo[a]pyrene (B(a)P) and mitomycin C (MMC) in cultured CHO cells and mice.
results_summary: Rooibos tea suppressed chromosome aberrations in CHO cells and reduced micronuclei in mice when exposed to mutagens, suggesting antimutagenic effects. Unlike green tea and Po-lei tea, RT's effects were observed both with and without metabolic activation (S9 mix), indicating potential unknown antimutagenic components.
population_specificity: Cultured CHO cells and mice.
effective_dosage: 0.1% RT at 1.0 ml/mouse (single dose for MMC, daily for 28 days for B(a)P).
study_duration: Single dose (6h before MMC) or 28 days (daily for B(a)P).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Rosa damascena essential oil (RDEO) on learning, memory, and biochemical markers in a rat model of scopolamine-induced amnesia, as well as its potential interaction with human M1 mAChR.
results_summary: RDEO mitigated learning and memory impairments in rats, reduced acetylcholinesterase activity, and increased M1 mAChR and BDNF levels. Computational modeling showed favorable binding of RDEO components to human M1 mAChR.
population_specificity: Scopolamine-induced amnestic rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the neuroprotective potential of Rose Essential Oil (REO) in a transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans model of Parkinson's disease.
results_summary: REO reduced α-synuclein aggregations, diminished dopaminergic neuron degeneration, improved food-sensing behavior, prolonged lifespan, and enhanced proteasome and SOD-3 activities while reducing oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Transgenic Caenorhabditis elegans (nematode) models of Parkinson's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether rose essential oil industry by-products could be valorized to extract pectic polysaccharides with gelling properties comparable to commercial citrus pectins.
results_summary: The study found that rose oil by-products, particularly those extracted with 1,1,1,2-tetrafluoroethane and hexane, yielded pectic polysaccharides with strong gelling properties, comparable to commercial citrus pectins. The highest polysaccharide yield was observed in Rosa damascena by-products, with rheological studies confirming strong gel formation under specific conditions.
population_specificity: Industrial by-products from Rosa damascena, Rosa alba, and Rosa centifolia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Pingyin rose essential oil (PREO) could alleviate and restore intestinal barrier damage induced by dextran sodium sulfate (DSS) in mice.
results_summary: PREO treatment improved colitis symptoms, increased tight junction proteins and antioxidant enzyme activities, reduced inflammatory markers, and modulated gut microbiota composition, suggesting potential benefits for gut barrier function via the TLR4-NF-kB pathway.
population_specificity: C57BL6 female mice with DSS-induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if rose essential oil aromatherapy reduces nausea and vomiting in chemotherapy patients.
results_summary: The study found that rose essential oil significantly reduced nausea and vomiting scores in chemotherapy patients compared to the control group, particularly in the second cycle of chemotherapy. The effect was consistent across multiple time periods post-chemotherapy.
population_specificity: 66 cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
study_duration: From November 2022 to March 2023 (exact duration per patient not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the anti-inflammatory and antioxidative mechanisms of Rose Essential Oil (PREO) using molecular analysis and network pharmacology.
results_summary: PREO significantly reduced inflammatory and oxidative biomarkers (NO, ROS, MDA) and preserved antioxidant enzyme activities (SOD, CAT). Network pharmacology and molecular docking suggested PREO's anti-inflammatory effects may involve regulation of the NF-κB signaling pathway.
population_specificity: RAW 264.7 cells (murine macrophage cell line) exposed to LPS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop an enzyme-based protocol using horseradish peroxidase (HRP) to remove allergenic eugenol from rose essential oil while preserving its organoleptic quality and chemical composition.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that HRP effectively removed allergenic eugenol from rose essential oil without compromising its organoleptic properties or chemical makeup. This enzyme-based approach presents a novel method for detoxifying natural extracts used in perfumery and cosmetics.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether rose essential oil, as an adjuvant to diclofenac sodium, could enhance pain relief in individuals with primary dysmenorrhea.
results_summary: The study found that both groups (diclofenac alone and diclofenac with rose essential oil aromatherapy) showed significant pain reduction at 10 and 30 minutes, but the group receiving rose essential oil had lower pain scores at 30 minutes compared to the diclofenac-only group.
population_specificity: 100 patients with primary dysmenorrhea.
effective_dosage: 2% rose essential oil (specific frequency not mentioned).
study_duration: Single intervention (measured at 10 and 30 minutes post-administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine whether inhalation aromatherapy with rose essential oil could reduce anxiety in patients undergoing coronary artery bypass graft (CABG) surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in state anxiety, trait anxiety, or total anxiety in CABG patients who inhaled rose essential oil compared to the control group. The results suggest that rose essential oil did not effectively alleviate preoperative anxiety in this context.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing CABG surgery (n=66).
effective_dosage: Three drops of 4% rose essential oil, inhaled for 10 minutes.
study_duration: Administered one night and one hour before surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of a fermented oat meal drink containing rosehip on glycaemic and insulinaemic responses in healthy adults.
results_summary: The rosehip drink (RFOMD) resulted in high glucose responses similar to the reference bread, but the study did not report significant effects on insulin response compared to the control. The primary focus of the study was on bilberry-enriched drinks, which showed more notable effects.
population_specificity: Young healthy adults
effective_dosage: 10% rosehip in fermented oat meal drink

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of Lady Prelox® (containing rose hip extract) on sexual function and oxidative stress in women with moderate sexual dysfunction.
results_summary: Supplementation with Lady Prelox® significantly improved FSFI scores and reduced oxidative stress compared to controls, with no reported adverse effects. The improvements were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: 100 healthy women aged 37-45 years with moderate sexual dysfunction.
effective_dosage: 50 mg Rosvita® rose hip extract (as part of Lady Prelox® tablets, taken daily for 8 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the land utilization efficiency and competitive dynamics of intercropping Roselle (Hibiscus sabdariffa L.) with cluster bean under different planting patterns and lithovit (CO2 nano-material) application rates.
results_summary: The study found that intercropping Roselle with cluster bean in a 1:3 row ratio achieved the highest land equivalent ratio (LER), area time equivalent ratio (ATER), and land utilization efficiency (LUE%), indicating improved productivity. Roselle was dominant in the intercropping system, while cluster bean was dominated, as evidenced by positive aggressivity for Roselle and negative for cluster bean.
population_specificity: Experimental farm setting at Zagazig University, Egypt, during summer seasons of 2018 and 2019.
effective_dosage: Lithovit rates of 0.0, 2.0, 4.0, and 6.0 g/l were tested, but Roselle-specific dosage was not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the clinical effects of roselle drink on antioxidant activity, blood pressure, and skin condition in healthy adults.
results_summary: The study found that roselle drink significantly reduced blood pressure, improved antioxidant levels, and increased skin redness and moisture after 6 months of consumption. Phenolics and anthocyanins in roselle were identified as potential contributors to these health effects.
population_specificity: 39 healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effect of Roselle on blood pressure in adults with primary hypertension.
results_summary: The study found very low-certainty evidence that Roselle had no significant effect on systolic or diastolic blood pressure compared to placebo. Secondary outcomes like adverse effects, pulse pressure, and heart rate were not reported.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes mellitus (60 participants).
effective_dosage: 5600 mg of Roselle extract capsules (total dose).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of various sanitizing agents in reducing Salmonella contamination in roselle seeds.
results_summary: Diluted vinegar and water at 55°C were effective in reducing Salmonella in roselle seeds by 2.48 and 2.54 log, respectively, with no negative impact on seed germination. High concentrations of NaOCl and ACEW showed lower antimicrobial activity.
population_specificity: Roselle seeds (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the active ingredients and molecular mechanism of Roselle (Hibiscus sabdariffa L.) in treating diabetes, focusing on its protective effects on vascular endothelial cells.
results_summary: The study found that Roselle has significant anti-hyperglycemic efficacy and a protective effect on vascular endothelial cells, supported by network pharmacology and experimental validation. It identified active ingredients and potential molecular mechanisms for Roselle's antidiabetic effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (likely in vitro or animal models based on methodology).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether roselle extract could mitigate cardiac hypertrophy and dysfunction following myocardial infarction (MI) in both in vivo and in vitro models.
results_summary: Roselle extract significantly improved cardiac function (LVDP, LVdP/dtmax, Tau) and reduced oxidative stress and cardiac remodeling markers in MI-induced rats. In vitro, it attenuated ANG II-induced cardiomyocyte hypertrophy in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats (in vivo) and H9c2 cardiomyocytes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antimicrobial effects of roselle-capped silver nanochips against Aggregatibacter actinomycetemcomitans and assess their toxicity on fibroblast cells for potential use in periodontitis treatment.
results_summary: The SNP-Ro chips demonstrated significant antimicrobial activity, eradicating A. actinomycetemcomitans within 180 minutes, and showed increased viability of human gingival fibroblasts compared to controls. The study suggests the SNP-Ro chip could be a promising adjunctive antimicrobial agent for periodontal therapy.
population_specificity: Human gingival fibroblasts (HGFs) and bacterial cultures of A. actinomycetemcomitans.
effective_dosage: Not specified (three ratios tested, but exact concentrations not provided).
study_duration: Not specified (time-kill assay conducted over 180 minutes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of roselle extract on early cardiac remodeling in a rat model of myocardial infarction (MI).
results_summary: Roselle supplementation attenuated cardiac injury markers (troponin-T), reduced inflammation (IL-6, IL-10), and mitigated fibrosis and hypertrophy in MI rats. The study concluded that roselle could limit early cardiac remodeling post-MI.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats (200-300 g) with induced MI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of aromatherapy with rose essential oil (REO) on apparent anxiety in patients with acute myocardial infarction (MI).
results_summary: The study found that REO significantly reduced anxiety levels in patients with acute MI, as measured by the Spielberger questionnaire, with a notable decrease in mean anxiety scores post-intervention compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Patients with acute MI admitted to the cardiac ward of Heshmatieh Hospital in Sabzevar.
effective_dosage: Three drops of REO by inhalation, three times a day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to understand the effects of pH and heat treatment on the stability, color, and antioxidant properties of anthocyanins in Roselle extract.
results_summary: The study found that Roselle extract is rich in anthocyanins with strong antioxidant capacity (DPPH IC50 = 4.06 mg/mL, ABTS IC50 = 3.7 mg/mL). Anthocyanins showed heat resistance and color stability in acidic environments but degraded rapidly in low-acid conditions.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to extract microcrystalline cellulose (MCC) from roselle fiber and compare its physicochemical, morphological, and thermal properties with commercially available MCC.
results_summary: The study found that roselle-derived MCC had higher crystallinity (78%) than commercial MCC (74%) and exhibited better thermal stability than roselle pulp but poorer stability compared to commercial MCC. The isolated MCC showed potential as a reinforcing element in green composites and a precursor for nanocellulose.
population_specificity: Not applicable (in vitro study on roselle fiber)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antibacterial effect of roselle calyx extracts compared to chemical agents on foodborne bacteria contaminating jalapeño and serrano peppers.
results_summary: Roselle calyx extracts significantly reduced levels of all 13 tested foodborne bacteria more effectively than sodium hypochlorite, colloidal silver, and acetic acid on both pepper types. The study suggests roselle extracts could be useful for disinfecting chili peppers in various settings.
population_specificity: Contaminated jalapeño and serrano peppers (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: Not specified (four extract types: water, methanol, acetone, ethyl acetate).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the antihypertensive efficacy and end-organ protective effects of a combination therapy of Hibiscus sabdariffa and Olea europaea extracts (Roselle-Olive) in an L-NAME-induced hypertensive rat model.
results_summary: Roselle-Olive demonstrated dose-dependent reductions in blood pressure, improved serum nitric oxide levels, enhanced liver and kidney markers, and showed antioxidant, genoprotective, and ACE-inhibitory effects. It also upregulated eNOS expression and reduced organ damage in hypertensive rats.
population_specificity: L-NAME-induced hypertensive rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of roselle calyces on serum lipid levels, insulin, inflammation, and oxidative stress in patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
results_summary: Roselle significantly reduced serum triglycerides (TG) and systolic blood pressure (SBP) compared to placebo, but no significant effects were observed on other measured variables.
population_specificity: Forty adult patients with metabolic syndrome (MetS).
effective_dosage: 500 mg of H. sabdariffa calyx powder once daily.

study_goal: To explore the effect of Roselle on blood pressure in hypertensive adult patients.
results_summary: No studies met the inclusion criteria, so there is insufficient evidence to support Roselle's benefit for controlling or lowering blood pressure in hypertensive patients. One ongoing study may meet the criteria when completed.
population_specificity: Hypertensive adult patients

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of regular Roselle ingestion on blood pressure and left ventricular hypertrophy in patients with moderate essential hypertension.
results_summary: Roselle significantly reduced pulse pressure, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and heart rate in both normotensive and hypertensive groups after 4 weeks, with effects reversing post-treatment. It also showed regression of left ventricular hypertrophy in hypertensive patients.
population_specificity: Normotensive subjects and patients with moderate essential hypertension (n=50 each, average age 50±5 years).
study_duration: 4 weeks of treatment followed by 4 weeks of recovery

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the mechanism behind the antihyperglycemic activity of an ethanolic extract of roselle calyxes (HS-EE) in diabetic rats.
results_summary: HS-EE at 1.0 g/kg/day significantly reduced blood glucose levels by 38% in diabetic rats and increased basal insulin levels in both normal and diabetic rats. It also increased the number of islets of Langerhans in both groups.
population_specificity: Male Sprague Dawley rats (normal and streptozotocin-induced diabetic).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effects of Roselle against cisplatin-induced reproductive toxicity in rats and study the underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: Roselle extract reduced cisplatin-induced sperm abnormalities, enhanced sperm motility, and restored antioxidant enzyme levels (SOD, GSH, CAT) and lipid peroxidation marker (MDA) to control levels in rats. The protective effects were attributed to its potent antioxidant activity.
population_specificity: Male albino rats
study_duration: 26 days (21 days pre-cisplatin and 5 days post-cisplatin)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of Hibiscus anthocyanins (HAs) from roselle on cell cycle arrest in human leukemia cells (HL-60) and analyze the underlying molecular mechanisms.
results_summary: HAs induced G2/M cell cycle arrest in HL-60 cells by increasing Tyr15 phosphorylation of Cdc2 and upregulating Cdk inhibitors p27 and p21. The study identified the ATM-Chk1/2-Cdc25C pathway as a critical mechanism for this arrest, suggesting HAs as a potential anticancer candidate.
population_specificity: Human leukemia cell line HL-60
